div.head: Facsimiles
div.p:
This chapter describes the usage of the facsimile module its elements and attributes. Facsimiles contain a representation of some written source in the form of a set of images, so the chapter defines a module intended for use in the representation of sources. The following paragraphs recommend the usage of the allowed elements and attributes in a MEI file and discusses the way of encoding transcription of such material. This module seems to be useful for the encoding of critical editions, but therefore it is recommend to use the elements of the critapp module. In this section elements and attributes will be presented, designed to support various possibilities in this module and discuss the associated mechanisms provided by theses Guidelines.
Overview of the facsimile Module
The module includes elements and attributes for encoding facsimiles which are in the simplest way a collection of images with some metadata.

The surface element defines a written surface as a two-dimensional coordinate space on some physical surface forming part of the source material such as a piece of paper or anything else, optionally grouping one or more graphic representations of that space and zones. A surface establishes a coordinate system which may be used to address parts or the whole of some digital representation of a written surface. To define coordinates it is recommend to use the specific attributes which are part of the att.coordinated.class. illustrated in the following example. The @ulx, @uly, @lrx and the @lry (...). The startid attribute may be used to hold a reference to the first feature occurring on this surface. The surface element is modelled on an element in the Text Encoding Initiative (TEI).
The surface element may however contain graphic representations of zones and indicates the location of an inline graphic illustration, or figure. For further information please read the chapter (X).
The following example illustrates the usage of the graphic element within a surface element. It is also possible to encode more than one graphic in a facsimile.
The example shows the graphic element within a surface element which indicates the location of an illustration. The graphic element is member of the figtable Module, so please read that chapter for further information about the graphic element and its usage in a MEI file.
A zone, by contrast to the surface element, defines any arbitrary area of interest relative to that surface, using the same coordinate system and defines a rectangular area within a surface element. The position of every zone for a given surface is always defined by reference to the coordinate system defined for that surface.

The zone element may be enriched by some attributes similar to those allowed on surface and may contain the graphic and the figDesc element. The zone element makes it possible to describe and define any region of interest, such a detail or a illustration.
The facs attribute permits the current element to reference a facsimile image or zone which corresponds to it. The following examples show how to use the attributes on several elements.

The image indicated by the facs attribute represents the whole of the music following the pb element.
